member.name: T:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase
member.summary: Implements a base class for a standard background process with control and synchronization elements in place. Derived classes provide the code to be executed at regular intervals.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.isDisposed
member.summary: Used for the disposable pattern. This variable is true once the type has been disposed of.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.delayInterval
member.summary: The number of milliseconds to delay between each execution.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.timer
member.summary: The timer class used to manage the execution calls to the derived classes Execute method.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.controlLock
member.summary: A synchronization object used to ensure only one control method is being called at any given time.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.#ctor
member.summary: This default constructor prepares the timer and sets the initial running state to false.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.Finalize
member.summary: The destructor ensures that the dispose method is called for resource cleanup.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.Start
member.summary:
This method starts the service and when it enters running state it will begin to call the derived types Execute method. There is a synchronization object that manages these control methods to ensure only one control method can be executed at a time. If the service is in paused or stopped state it will try to enter the Running state. If the derived classes Resuming (if in paused state) or Starting (if in stopped state) methods return false it will fail back to the original state.
Trying to start a service that is in the pausing, resuming or stopping states will result in a ControlInvalidException exception.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.Stop
member.summary:
This method stops the service and stops calling the derived types Execute method. There is a synchronization object that manages these control methods to ensure only one control method can be executed at a time. If the service is in paused or running state it will try to enter the Stopped state. If the derived classes Stopping method return false it will fail back to the original state.
Trying to stop a service that is in the resuming, pausing, stopping or starting states will result in a ControlInvalidException exception.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.Resume
member.summary:
This method resumes the service and when it enters running state it will begin to call the derived types Execute method. There is a synchronization object that manages these control methods to ensure only one control method can be executed at a time. If the service is in the paused state it will try to enter the Running state. If the derived classes Resuming (if in the paused state) method return false it will fail back to the original state.
Trying to resume a service that is in the pausing, stopped, starting or stopping states will result in a ControlInvalidException exception.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.Pause
member.summary:
This method pauses the service and no longer calls the derived types Execute method. There is a synchronization object that manages these control methods to ensure only one control method can be executed at a time. If the service is in the running state it will try to enter the Paused state. If the derived classes Pausing (if in the running state) method return false it will fail back to the original state.
Trying to resume a service that is in the resuming, pausing, starting, stopped or stopping states will result in a ControlInvalidException exception.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.Starting
member.summary:
This method is called to allow the derived class to perform activities when the service is starting. This is synchronous and the service will remain in the starting state until it completes. If the method returns false the service will fail to start.
No service control methods should be called from within this method.
member.returns: True is returned if the service should continue to start, false if the service should not start.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.Stopping
member.summary:
This method is called to allow the derived class to perform activities when the service is stopping. This is synchronous and the service will remain in the stopping state until it completes. If the method returns false the service will fail to stop.
No service control methods should be called from within this method.
member.returns: True is returned if the service should continue to stop, false if the service should not stop.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.Resuming
member.summary:
This method is called to allow the derived class to perform activities when the service is resuming. This is synchronous and the service will remain in the resuming state until it completes. If the method returns false the service will fail to resume.
No service control methods should be called from within this method.
member.returns: True is returned if the service should resume, false if the service should not resume.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.Pausing
member.summary:
This method is called to allow the derived class to perform activities when the service is pausing. This is synchronous and the service will remain in the pausing state until it completes. If the method returns false the service will fail to pause.
No service control methods should be called from within this method.
member.returns: True is returned if the service should continue to pause, false if the service should not pause.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.Execute
member.summary: This method should contain the derived types code that will be called at each interval. This will only be called while the service is in a running state.
member.returns: true if the execute method should be immediately called again, false to wait for the next interval.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.Dispose
member.summary: This method should be called when the instance is no longer needed. This cleans up resources.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.DisposeOfObjects
member.summary: This method can be overloaded to cleanup resources in the derived types. This method will only be called one time when the class is disposed of.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.BackgroundServiceBase.Dispose(System.Boolean)
member.summary: This method is called from Dispose and terminators to provide a common set of cleanup logic. Once this is called from the IDisposable interface it will also remove the class from the finalizer queue.
member.param: true if the method is called from the Dispose method, false if from the terminator

member.name: T:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Compute.PrimaryInstanceManager
member.summary:
This class is used to manage active / passive relationships between instances. The relationship is managed through the use of a BlobWaitHandle where the instance that possesses the lease on the wait handle is viewed as primary. A sample usage of this would be in a scheduler where you want a single instance to execute the event when it occurs but need the SLA and availability / reliability of multiple instances.
When the class is initiated through initial start call the instance will always be secondary. Each control of the service (ex. stop, start, resume, pause) will trigger a 10 second delay before attempting to assume the primary role.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Compute.PrimaryInstanceManager.primaryRoleNotification
member.summary: Contains the method to notify the consumer of a role change to primary.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Compute.PrimaryInstanceManager.secondaryRoleNotification
member.summary: Contains the method to notify the consumer of a role change to secondary.

member.summary: This lock ensures that code logic is not being executed while the control events are called.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusEndpointInfo.IssuerName
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the service identity configured in Access Control for the Windows Azure Service Bus namespace.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusEndpointInfo.IssuerSecret
member.summary: Gets or sets the key for the service identity configured in Access Control for the Windows Azure Service Bus namespace.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusEndpointInfo.SharedAccessKeyName
member.summary: Gets or sets the Shared Access Signature (SAS) key name that describes the authorization rule configured on the Service Bus namespace, or on the messaging entity with which specific rights are associated. If the object was initialized from a connection string, this property will return the value of the SharedAccessKeyName parameter specified in the connection string. For more information on Shared Access Signature authentication with Service Bus, see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windowsazure/dn170477.aspx.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusEndpointInfo.SharedAccessKeyValue
member.summary: Gets or sets the Shared Access Signature (SAS) key name value. This value represents a 256-bit primary cryptographic key in Base64 representation. SAS authentication in Service Bus involves the use of this cryptographic key with associated rights on a Service Bus resource to protect against unauthorized access. Clients claim access to Service Bus resources by presenting a SAS token. This is done transparently by the Service Bus brokered messaging API. If the object was initialized from a connection string, this property will return the value of the SharedAccessKey parameter specified in the connection string. For more information on Shared Access Signature authentication with Service Bus, visit http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windowsazure/dn170477.aspx.

member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the queue endpoint in Windows Azure Service Bus.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusEndpointInfo.HostName
member.summary: Gets or sets the server name hosting the Windows Azure Service Bus endpoint. Depending on the version of Windows Azure Service Bus, it is either the fully qualified DNS name ending with servicebus.windows.net, or the machine name that is resolvable through the local DNS.

member.summary: Gets the flag indicating whether or not the object addresses an endpoint on the Windows Azure Service Bus cloud-based service as opposed to on-premises version of Windows Azure Service Bus usually referred to as "Windows Service Bus".

member.name: T:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings
member.summary: Implements a configuration element containing runtime settings for the component.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.MaximumLockDuration
member.summary: Gets the maximum lock duration allowed by the underlying messaging infrastructure.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.MaximumTimeToLive
member.summary: Gets the maximum message time-to-live (TTL) allowed by the underlying messaging infrastructure.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.MaximumWaitTimeout
member.summary: Gets the maximum message wait timeout allowed by the underlying messaging infrastructure.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of a object with default settings.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.MessageWaitTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the custom time value indicating how long Service Bus messaging API will keep a communication channel open while waiting for a new message.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.MessageLockDuration
member.summary: Gets or sets the custom duration during which the messages that are being processed remain marked as in-flight and invisible to other competing consumers (if any).

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.MessageTimeToLive
member.summary: Gets or sets the custom time-to-live (TTL) value for published messages. The messages older than their TTL will be removed before they can reach the subscribers.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.PrefetchCount
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of messages that the message receiver can simultaneously request. Use PrefetchCount to fetch multiple messages from the server in the same round-trip. This can be useful in scenarios that need lower latency for receiving existing messages from a subscription. Prefetch can also improve throughput depending upon the scenarios as the number of round-trips to the server are reduced.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.UseSharedConnection
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag enabling a connection share between publishers and subscribers. When enabled, publishers and subscribers share the same connection to the underlying messaging infrastructure. When disabled, a dedicated connection is established to the underlying messaging infrastructure to server all publishers and subscribers in isolation.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.UsePeekLock
member.summary: Gets or sets the flag enabling the PeekLock mode when receiving messages from a subscription. With the PeekLock mode, the receive process becomes a two-stage operation making it possible to support scenarios that cannot tolerate failed messages.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.UseDuplicateDetection
member.summary: Gets or sets the value indicating whether the duplicate detection functionality must be enforced when accepting messages from the publisher.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.DuplicateDetectionWindow
member.summary: Gets or sets the time value that defines how long message IDs will be retained in the messaging infrastructure in order to detect duplicates.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.UseDeadLettering
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the global dead letter support is enabled either when a message expires or when filter evaluation doesn't succeed.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.UseHttps
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that instructs the Service Bus messaging API to use the HTTPS-based protocol for connectivity, as opposed to the TCP-based SBMP protocol, which is the default choice of the messaging API.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.MaxSizeInMegabytes
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum size of the topic in megabytes, which is the size of message store allocated for the topic.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.ReceiveBatchSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of messages to be received as a single batch.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.SendBatchSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of messages to be published as a single batch.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannelSettings.Default
member.summary: Returns default settings.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ExtendedCommandBehavior
member.summary: Provides the extended description of the results of the query and its effect on the database. This enumeration extends the standard . It is decorated with a attribute that allows a bitwise combination of its member values.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ExtendedCommandBehavior.Default
member.summary: The query may return multiple result sets. Execution of the query may affect the database state. Default sets no CommandBehavior flags, so calling ExecuteReader(CommandBehavior.Default) is functionally equivalent to calling ExecuteReader().

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ExtendedCommandBehavior.SingleResult
member.summary: The query returns a single result set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ExtendedCommandBehavior.SchemaOnly
member.summary: The query returns column information only. When using SchemaOnly, the .NET Framework Data Provider for SQL Server precedes the statement being executed with SET FMTONLY ON.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ExtendedCommandBehavior.KeyInfo
member.summary: The query returns column and primary key information. When KeyInfo is used for command execution, the provider will append extra columns to the result set for existing primary key and timestamp columns.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ExtendedCommandBehavior.SingleRow
member.summary: The query is expected to return a single row of the first result set.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ExtendedCommandBehavior.SequentialAccess
member.summary: Provides a way for the DataReader to handle rows that contain columns with large binary values. Rather than loading the entire row, SequentialAccess enables the DataReader to load data as a stream. You can then use the GetBytes or GetChars method to specify a byte location to start the read operation, and a limited buffer size for the data being returned. When you specify SequentialAccess, you are required to read from the columns in the order they are returned, although you are not required to read each column.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ExtendedCommandBehavior.CloseConnection
member.summary: When the command is executed, the associated connection object is closed when the associated DataReader object is closed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ExtendedCommandBehavior.ClearPoolOnTimeout
member.summary:
When the command execution results in a SQL timeout, the associated connection object will be forcibly removed from the connection pool so that a new connection can be re-established to the database.
In some rare cases, the SQL timeout exceptions could become sticky to the underlying (potentially broken) physical connection to a Windows Azure SQL database. From a client application perspective, it may seem like a long-lasting transient fault that continuously results in a query timeout exception and never recovers. One potential remedy is to force the physical connection to close and reopen by cleaning the specific SQL connection pool holding off the broken connection. This particular flag enables the above behavior by permitting the to clear the connection pool.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingCondition.IsThrottledOnDataSpace

member.summary: Returns a flag indicating that CPU throttling was reported by SQL Azure.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingCondition.IsThrottledOnDatabaseSize
member.summary: Returns a flag indicating that database size throttling was reported by SQL Azure.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingCondition.IsThrottledOnWorkerThreads
member.summary: Returns a flag indicating that concurrent requests throttling was reported by SQL Azure.

member.name: P:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingCondition.IsUnknown
member.summary: Returns a flag indicating that throttling conditions were not determined with certainty.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingMode
member.summary: Defines the possible throttling modes in SQL Azure.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingMode.NoThrottling
member.summary: Corresponds to "No Throttling" throttling mode whereby all SQL statements can be processed.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingMode.RejectUpdateInsert
member.summary: Corresponds to "Reject Update / Insert" throttling mode whereby SQL statements such as INSERT, UPDATE, CREATE TABLE and CREATE INDEX are rejected.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingMode.RejectAllWrites
member.summary: Corresponds to "Reject All Writes" throttling mode whereby SQL statements such as INSERT, UPDATE, DELETE, CREATE, DROP are rejected.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingMode.RejectAll
member.summary: Corresponds to "Reject All" throttling mode whereby all SQL statements are rejected.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingMode.Unknown
member.summary: Corresponds to an unknown throttling mode whereby throttling mode cannot be determined with certainty.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingType
member.summary: Defines the possible throttling types in SQL Azure.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingType.None
member.summary: Indicates that no throttling was applied to a given resource.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingType.Soft
member.summary: Corresponds to a Soft throttling type. Soft throttling is applied when machine resources such as, CPU, IO, storage, and worker threads exceed predefined safety thresholds despite the load balancers best efforts.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingType.Hard
member.summary: Corresponds to a Hard throttling type. Hard throttling is applied when the machine is out of resources, for example storage space. With hard throttling, no new connections are allowed to the databases hosted on the machine until resources are freed up.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottlingType.Unknown
member.summary: Corresponds to an unknown throttling type in the event when the throttling type cannot be determined with certainty.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottledResourceType
member.summary: Defines the types of resources in SQL Azure which may be subject to throttling conditions.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottledResourceType.PhysicalDatabaseSpace
member.summary: Corresponds to "Physical Database Space" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottledResourceType.PhysicalLogSpace
member.summary: Corresponds to "Physical Log File Space" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottledResourceType.LogWriteIODelay
member.summary: Corresponds to "Transaction Log Write IO Delay" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottledResourceType.DataReadIODelay
member.summary: Corresponds to "Database Read IO Delay" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottledResourceType.CPU
member.summary: Corresponds to "CPU" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottledResourceType.DatabaseSize
member.summary: Corresponds to "Database Size" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottledResourceType.WorkerThreads
member.summary: Corresponds to "SQL Worker Thread Pool" resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottledResourceType.Internal
member.summary: Corresponds to an internal resource which may be subject to throttling.

member.name: F:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Data.ThrottledResourceType.Unknown
member.summary: Corresponds to an unknown resource type in the event when the actual resource cannot be determined with certainty.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.FrameworkUtility.ObfuscateConnectionString(System.String)
member.summary: Removes sensitive security information such as passwords, shared secret keys and storage account keys from the specified connection string. Returns a new connection string which includes a canonical placeholder in place of the sensitive information. The obfuscated connection string value can then be used for logging purposes, which in turn ensures a level of compliance with the applicable software security standards such as PCI-DSS.
member.param: The original connection string to be obfuscated.
member.returns: The obfuscated connection string with sensitive security information replaced with a canonical <OBFUSCATED> placeholder.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Diagnostics.HybridTraceEventProvider
member.summary: Implements a tracing component that uses either local ETW tracing infrastructure or Windows Azure diagnostic monitor API to log the application trace events.

remarks.para: Depending on the execution environment, this component will adjust its internal functionality to match the most common needs of the developer.

When running in the context of a cloud application, this class will automatically use the component to route all tracing events to. In addition, it recognizes whether or not the application is running inside the Windows Azure Compute Emulator. If so, this class will also engage the Development Fabric trace listener into tracing activities, which will result in trace events being displayed directly in the Compute Emulator's console.

By contrast, when running outside the cloud environment, the class will switch over to use the ETW tracing infrastructure. It will use the specified provider GUID to configure the ETW event provider. Once this is set up, the standard ETW tracing tools such as TraceView can be used to get insights into the application's behavior, provided the application is instrumented using the component. In addition, when the developer is running the instrumented application inside the Visual Studio debugger, the class will automatically enable the default diagnostic trace listener. By doing this, the class allows the developer to see the trace events inside the Visual Studio IDE or using the familiar tools such as DebugView, which in turn translates into a better developer experience during troubleshooting or testing.

The trace level can be controlled by configuring the Windows Azure Diagnostic Monitor for cloud applications or specifying the desired level in the ETW tool for on-premises applications. To control the level of tracing when running inside the debugger, a trace switch called CloudFx.Diagnostics.DefaultTraceSwitch can be added to the application's configuration file. For more information about trace switches, refer to http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/t06xyy08.aspx.

remarks.para: The property can be used for routing messages to a particular endpoint defined in the application configuration. For instance, the default implementation of the component uses this property to send messages to a specific Windows Azure Service Bus topic, which is described in the application configuration under a given endpoint name.
The value specified in the property can also be a regular expression. This will allow routing messages to multiple endpoints that match the specified expression.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.ScalableServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannel
member.summary: Implements a messaging component that supports publish-subscribe capability using Windows Azure Service Bus and is capable of scaling out across multiple topics to support a very large number of publishers and subscribers.
Initializes a new instance of a object using a collection of the specified Service Bus topic endpoints and optional settings.
member.param: The value identifying a given client of the messaging component. This value determines which topic a particular client is assigned to.
The Service Bus endpoint collection using which the messaging component will be leveraging to provide scalable publish-subscribe capability.
The optional object containing behavioral and runtime settings for the messaging component.
The optional retry policy that will ensure reliable access to the underlying messaging infrastructure.
member.remarks:
The parameter is very important in the context of scale-out across multiple topics. This value needs to uniquely identify the instance of the messaging client, which can be a deterministic, durable number (such as that it survives machine reboots or failovers) or a random number (such as that it is assigned at runtime from a pool of random values).
The former use case is better suited for messaging scenarios where a client can either persist or reliably determine its ID at runtime and it never changes between restarts. A good example of such a value could be the role instance's index assigned by the Windows Azure Fabric Controller upon provisioning. See for more details on how to obtain the index value from a given role instance ID. By using the deterministic ID value, the clients can be guaranteed to be assigned to the same topic which they were connected to prior to reboot.
The later use case is mostly suited the scenarios where messaging clients are volatile in nature and don't have to receive messages while they are offline. Every time a client uses the component with a different ID, the client will be assigned to a different topic depending on the ID value.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.ScalableServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannel.Publish``1(System.IObservable{``0})
member.summary: Publishes one or more messages returned by the specified provider into the underlying publish-subscribe messaging infrastructure.
member.typeparam: The type of the message to be published.
member.param: The provider supplying messages for publication.
member.returns: The object which enables the consumer to track the progress of the publishing operation, be notified when an error occurs or when the operation finishes.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.ScalableServiceBusPublishSubscribeChannel.Subscribe``1(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean)

member.summary: Synchronously publishes the specified message along with its optional properties into the underlying publish-subscribe messaging infrastructure.
member.remarks: This extension method provides a simplified interface to the publish-subscribe messaging infrastructure. It allows publishing a single message with optional properties. If publication fails, the method will reflect this by throwing an with the original exception that caused the publication to fail.
member.typeparam: The type of the message to be published.
member.param: The instance of the for which the extension method will be invoked.
The message to be published.
The optional message properties to be published along with the message.
member.returns: True if the message was successfully published, otherwise false.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.ExtensionMethods.PublishAsync``1(Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.IPublishSubscribeChannel,``0,System.Collections.Generic.IDictionary{System.String,System.Object},System.Action{System.Exception},System.Action)
member.summary: Asynchronously publishes the specified message along with its optional properties into the underlying publish-subscribe messaging infrastructure.
member.typeparam: The type of the message to be published.
member.param: The instance of the for which the extension method will be invoked.
The message to be published.
The optional message properties to be published along with the message.
The optional action that gets invoked if the underlying asynchronous operation completes with an error.
The optional action that gets invoked if the underlying asynchronous operation completes successfully.
member.returns: A disposable object which represents a callback subscription to the underlying asynchronous operation. Disposing the subscription will result in blocking the caller until the asynchronous operation is finished, either successfully or with a failure.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.ExtensionMethods.Publish``1(Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.IPublishSubscribeChannel,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Synchronously publishes the specified list of messages into the underlying publish-subscribe messaging infrastructure optionally enforcing transactional atomicity of the operation.

remarks.para: This extension method provides a simplified interface to the publish-subscribe messaging infrastructure. It allows publishing the specified collection of messages synchronously. If any message in the collection fails to be published, the method will reflect this by throwing an with the original exception that caused the publication to fail. The parameter defines how the publish-subscribe infrastructure treats the messages being published. If it is set to True, all messages will be published in a single transaction. In this case, if publication fails, none of the messages will be retained in the messaging infrastructure.
The maximum allowed size of the atomic batch is 100 messages. This limitation may change in the future.

member.typeparam: The type of the message to be published.
member.param: The instance of the for which the extension method will be invoked.
The list of messages to be published.
The optional flag indicating whether or not the publishing operation must be performed atomically.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.ExtensionMethods.PublishAsync``1(Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.IPublishSubscribeChannel,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Asynchronously publishes the specified list of messages into the underlying publish-subscribe messaging infrastructure optionally enforcing transactional atomicity of the operation.

member.returns: A disposable object which represents a callback subscription to the underlying asynchronous operation. Disposing the subscription will result in blocking the caller until the asynchronous operation is finished, either successfully or with a failure.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.ExtensionMethods.Subscribe``1(Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.IPublishSubscribeChannel,System.IObserver{``0},System.Int32,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Subscribes the observer to receive messages of the specified type that match the specified optional filter. Allows customization in the number of concurrent listeners that will be receiving messages either as competing or non-competing consumers. The subscription name will be assigned automatically by computing a hashed value which combines the assembly-qualified name of the type and the specified filter. In addition, if non-competing consumers are being requested, the computed subscription name will include a special placeholder {0} which is required in order to customize the subscription name for each individual consumer.
member.typeparam: The type of messages that the observer will be subscribed to.
member.param: The instance of the for which the extension method will be invoked.
The observer for messages of the specified type .
The number of concurrent listeners receiving messages of the given type.
The optional filter expressed in the specific syntax that can be understood by the underlying publish-subscribe messaging infrastructure.
The optional flag indicating whether or not the created subscription will be retained in the underlying publish-subscribe messaging infrastructure even it does not have active subscribers.
The optional flag enabling or disabling the listeners to act as competing consumers.
member.returns: The instance of an object that enables cancelling a subscription by the consumer.

member.summary: Projects the Windows Azure Service Bus namespace as an observable sequence of objects carrying telemetry information about the namespace and its messaging entities, such as topic size, subscription queue depth, etc. This class can act as a data source for monitoring purposes.

The issuer name which will be used for connecting to the namespace.
The issuer secret which will be used for connecting to the namespace.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.ServiceBusNamespaceObserver.#ctor(Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusEndpointInfo,System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of a object using the specified Service Bus endpoint. The endpoint can describe either a particular queue or topic to be observed. If no specific endpoint type is defined in the property, the entire namespace will be observed, which will include all queues and topics found in the Windows Azure Service Bus namespace that is described in the specified .
member.param: The Service Bus endpoint using which the component will be observing.
The time interval which defines how often the component will be collecting telemetry from Windows Azure Service Bus and dispatching notifications to the active subscribers.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.ServiceBusNamespaceObserver.#ctor(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Configuration.ServiceBusEndpointInfo},System.TimeSpan)

The specified collection can include the endpoints that describe either a particular queue or topic to be observed. If no specific endpoint type is defined in the property, the entire namespace will be observed, which will include all queues and topics found in each Windows Azure Service Bus namespace that is provided in the collection.
member.param: The collection of Service Bus endpoint using which the component will be observing.
The time interval which defines how often the component will be collecting telemetry from Windows Azure Service Bus and dispatching notifications to the active subscribers.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Messaging.ServiceBusRequestResponseChannel
member.summary: Implements a component that supports request/response message exchange pattern using a pair of one-way publish/subscribe messaging channels.

Initializes a new instance of a object using the specified pair of request and response endpoints. These endpoints will be utilized for creating underlying messaging channels to send requests and receive responses respectively.
member.param: The user-defined name that uniquely identifies a party involved in the request-response message exchange.
The Service Bus messaging endpoint that will be used for receiving requests.
The Service Bus messaging endpoint that will be used for sending responses.
The optional object containing behavioral and runtime settings for this messaging component.
The optional retry policy that will ensure reliable access to the underlying messaging infrastructure.
The optional serializer that will define how requests and response messages are represented on the wire.
member.para: The parameter specifies the name of the connected party that communicates with other parties using the request-response message exchange pattern. In most cases, this parameter would uniquely identify both a requestor (sending requests) and a replier (responding with replies) so that responses will reach the right clients.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of a object using the specified pair of request and response channel. These channels will be utilized for sending requests and receiving responses respectively.
member.param: The user-defined name that uniquely identifies a party involved in the request-response message exchange.
The messaging channel that will be used for receiving requests.
The messaging channel that will be used for sending responses.
The optional object containing behavioral and runtime settings for the messaging component.
The optional serializer that will define how requests and response messages are represented on the wire.
member.para: The parameter specifies the name of the connected party that communicates with other parties using the request-response message exchange pattern. member.summary: Provides a base class for custom implementations of Windows Azure web roles.

member.name: T:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.CloudWorkerRoleBase
member.summary: Provides a base class for Windows Azure worker roles that share common functional and non-functional elements such as heartbeats, extension model, unhandled exception reporting.

member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the object initialized with default global settings.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.CloudWorkerRoleBase.OnStart
member.summary: Called by Windows Azure to initialize the role instance.
member.returns: True if initialization succeeds, otherwise false.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.CloudWorkerRoleBase.Run
member.summary: Called by Windows Azure after the role instance has been initialized. This method serves as the main thread of execution for your role.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.CloudWorkerRoleBase.OnStop
member.summary: Called by Windows Azure when the role instance is to be stopped.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.CloudWorkerRoleBase.OnRoleStart
member.summary: Enables the user code to extend the OnStart phase that is called by Windows Azure runtime to initialize the role instance.
member.returns: True if initialization succeeds, otherwise false.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.CloudWorkerRoleBase.OnRoleRun
member.summary: Enables the user code to extend the Run phase that is called by Windows Azure runtime after the role instance has been initialized.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.CloudWorkerRoleBase.OnRoleStop
member.summary: Enables the user code to extend the OnStop phase that is called by Windows Azure runtime when the role instance is to be stopped.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.CloudWorkerRoleBase.OnRoleEnvironmentChanging(System.Object,Microsoft.WindowsAzure.ServiceRuntime.RoleEnvironmentChangingEventArgs)
member.summary: Enables the user code to provide a handler for the event that occurs before a change to the service configuration is applied to the running instances of the role.
member.param: The source of the event.
The event data.

member.summary: Enables the user code to provide a handler for the event that occurs after a change to the service configuration is applied to the running instances of the role.
member.param: The source of the event.
The event data.

member.param: The source of the unhandled exception event.
An that contains the event data.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.RetryPolicy.Subscribe(System.IObserver{System.Exception})
member.summary: Subscribes the specified to all transient faults detected by the error detection strategy used by this retry policy. The observer will only be notified upon encountering a transient condition. If a fault has not been detected as transient, the retry policy will relay the corresponding exception to the caller and will not notify the observer.
member.param: The object that will be receiving notifications about transient faults.
member.returns: A disposable subscription object that allows the subscriber to indicate whenever it wants to stop receiving notifications.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.RetryPolicy.Subscribe(System.IObserver{Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.RetryingEventArgs})
member.summary: Subscribes the specified to all transient faults detected by the error detection strategy used by this retry policy. The observer will only be notified upon encountering a transient condition. If a fault has not been detected as transient, the retry policy will relay the corresponding exception to the caller and will not notify the observer.
member.param: The object that will be receiving notifications about transient faults.
member.returns: A disposable subscription object that allows the subscriber to indicate whenever it wants to stop receiving notifications.

remarks.para: This overload is useful when a consumer is interested in receiving some extra information about transient faults such as the number of retry attempts occurred thus far, as well as the time delay during which the policy will wait before retrying the failed operation.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Storage.BlobWaitHandle.WaitOne(System.Int32)
member.summary: Wait until the lock is released or the timeout expires to continue. This wait may be longer if retries are required as control is not returned. If the timeout parameter is set to -1 it will be considered an infinite wait.
member.param: The number of milliseconds to wait for the lock to be cleared. This value must be between -1 and 2,147,483,647 milliseconds.
member.returns: Returns true if the blob lease is acquired successfully.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Storage.BlobWaitHandle.WaitOne(System.TimeSpan)
member.summary: Wait until the lock is released or the timeout expires to continue. This wait may be longer if retries are required as control is not returned. If the timeout parameter is set to -1 milliseconds it will be considered an infinite wait.
member.param: A TimeSpan to wait or continue if the lock is not released. This value must be between -1 and 2,147,483,647 milliseconds.
member.returns: Returns true if the blob was no longer leased. False is returned if the request times out.

member.summary: Waits for up to the timeout specified to acquire the lease. This wait may be longer if retries are required as control is not returned. If the timeout is set to -1 milliseconds it will be considered and infinite wait.

member.returns: True if the lease was acquired, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Storage.BlobWaitHandle.Reset(System.Int32)
member.summary: Waits up to the number of milliseconds specified to acquire the lease. This wait may be longer if retries are required as control is not returned. If the timeout is set to -1 milliseconds it will be considered and infinite wait.
member.param: The maximum duration in milliseconds to try and acquire the lease. The timeout must be between -1 and 2,147,483,647 milliseconds.
member.returns: True if the lease was acquired, false otherwise.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Storage.BlobWaitHandle.Set(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Releases the lock on the object and allows waiting threads to continue. When force is true this will reset the the lock even if the lease was not previously held by this object.
member.param: true to force the release of the lock (lease on the blob), false to only release if this object held a lock originally.
member.returns: True if the lock was released successfully.

Outputs the leaseId when the action is successful, null otherwise.

member.summary: This method is used to release a previously acquired lease based on the existingLeaseId.

The lease id that was previously obtained from the AcquireLease call.

member.summary: This method is used to terminate (break) an existing lease.
member.param: The blob for which the lease is to be broken.
member.returns: Success if the lease was broken successfully. Conflict will be returned if the lease could not be broken because the blob does not have an active lease. A return value of UnknownFailure may indicate an invalid HTTP response (other than Accepted).

member.param: The blob to renew the lease for.
The lease id from a previously acquired lease.
member.returns: Success if the lease was renewed successfully. Conflict will be returned if the lease being renewed ahs already been broken but not yet expired or there is no matching or active lease on the blob. Unknown Failure may indicate an invalid Http code being returned (not OK).

member.name: T:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Storage.ExcludeAttribute
member.summary:
Provides a declarative mechanism for excluding select properties from table entities.
The common use case for this attribute would be to exclude computed properties. For example, the developer may want to expose the PartitionKey to the rest of the application under a different name to reflect its business meaning. In this case, the developer will create a business domain-specific property that gets and sets the PartitionKey value, and is decorated with so that it doesn't get persisted to the table storage.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Storage.ExtensionMethods.Upsert``1(Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Storage.ICloudTableStorage,System.String,System.IObservable{``0},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enumerates through the entities returned by the specified provider and updates each entity if it already exists, or inserts a new entity if it doesn't exist in the target table. The Upsert action will save an extra roundtrip to the storage swhen an application wants to insert or update an entity without needing to know if the entity already exists or not. Upsert can help increase performance and decrease latencies in the described scenario.

remarks.para: The flag tells the Windows Azure Table storage infrastructure how it should treat the existing entities.

If is set to True, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist, or if the entity exists, replace the existing one. This means that once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with its properties, replacing the previous entity and all of its existing properties if it had previously existed.

If is set to False, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist or, if the entity exists, merges the specified entity's properties with the already existing ones. Once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with updated properties provided in the request.

member.typeparam: The type of the table entity.
member.param: The instance of the for which the extension method will be invoked.
The name of the table containing the entities.
The provider supplying the entities to be either updated or inserted.
A flag indicating whether the operation will replace the existing entity if it already exists.
member.returns: The object which enables the consumer to track the progress of the operation, and be notified when an error occurs or when the operation finishes.

member.summary: Enumerates through the specified collection of entities and updates each entity if it already exists, or inserts a new entity if it doesn't exist in the target table. The Upsert action will save an extra roundtrip to the storage system when an application wants to insert or update an entity without needing to know if the entity already exists or not. Upsert can help increase performance and decrease latencies in the described scenario.

remarks.para: The flag tells the Windows Azure Table storage infrastructure how it should treat the existing entities.

If is set to True, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist, or if the entity exists, replace the existing one. This means that once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with its properties, replacing the previous entity and all of its existing properties if it had previously existed.

If is set to False, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist or, if the entity exists, merges the specified entity's properties with the already existing ones. Once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with updated properties provided in the request.

member.typeparam: The type of the table entity.
member.param: The instance of the for which the extension method will be invoked.
The name of the table containing the entities.
The collection of entities to be either updated or inserted.
The number of entities to be batched together and sent in a single request. For optimal batch size, refer to the Windows Azure Table Storage API documentation.
The optional flag indicating whether the operation will replace the existing entity if it already exists.
member.returns: True if all the entities have been successfully updated or inserted, otherwise false.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Storage.ICloudTableRepository`1.Upsert(`0,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Updates the specified entity if it already exists, or inserts the entity if the specified entity doesn't exist in the target table. The Upsert action will save an extra roundtrip to the storage system when an application wants to insert or update an entity without needing to know if the entity already exists or not. Upsert can help increase performance and decrease latencies in the described scenario.
member.remarks:
The flag tells the Windows Azure Table storage infrastructure how it should treat the existing entities.
If is set to True, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist, or if the entity exists, replace the existing one. This means that once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with its properties, replacing the previous entity and all of its existing properties if it had previously existed.
If is set to False, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist or, if the entity exists, merges the specified entity's properties with the already existing ones. Once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with updated properties provided in the request.
member.param: The instance of the entity to be either updated or inserted.
A flag indicating whether the operation will replace the existing entity if it already exists.
member.returns: True if the entity has been successfully updated or inserted, otherwise False.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Storage.ICloudTableRepository`1.Upsert(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enumerates through the specified collection of entities and updates each entity if it already exists, or inserts a new entity if it doesn't exist in the target table. The Upsert action will save an extra roundtrip to the storage system when an application wants to insert or update an entity without needing to know if the entity already exists or not. Upsert can help increase performance and decrease latencies in the described scenario.

remarks.para: The flag tells the Windows Azure Table storage infrastructure how it should treat the existing entities.

If is set to True, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist, or if the entity exists, replace the existing one. This means that once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with its properties, replacing the previous entity and all of its existing properties if it had previously existed.

If is set to False, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist or, if the entity exists, merges the specified entity's properties with the already existing ones. Once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with updated properties provided in the request.

member.param: The collection of entities to be updated or inserted.
A flag indicating whether the operation will replace the existing entity if it already exists.
member.returns: True if all entities have been successfully updated or inserted, otherwise False.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Storage.ReliableCloudTableRepository`1.Upsert(`0,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Updates the specified entity if it already exists, or inserts the entity if the specified entity doesn't exist in the target table. The Upsert action will save an extra roundtrip to the storage system when an application wants to insert or update an entity without needing to know if the entity already exists or not. Upsert can help increase performance and decrease latencies in the described scenario.
member.remarks:
The flag tells the Windows Azure Table storage infrastructure how it should treat the existing entities.
If is set to True, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist, or if the entity exists, replace the existing one. This means that once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with its properties, replacing the previous entity and all of its existing properties if it had previously existed.
If is set to False, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist or, if the entity exists, merges the specified entity's properties with the already existing ones. Once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with updated properties provided in the request.
member.param: The instance of the entity to be either updated or inserted.
A flag indicating whether the operation will replace the existing entity if it already exists.
member.returns: True if the entity has been successfully updated or inserted, otherwise False.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Storage.ReliableCloudTableRepository`1.Upsert(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{`0},System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enumerates through the specified collection of entities and updates each entity if it already exists, or inserts a new entity if it doesn't exist in the target table. The Upsert action will save an extra roundtrip to the storage system when an application wants to insert or update an entity without needing to know if the entity already exists or not. Upsert can help increase performance and decrease latencies in the described scenario.

remarks.para: The flag tells the Windows Azure Table storage infrastructure how it should treat the existing entities.

If is set to True, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist, or if the entity exists, replace the existing one. This means that once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with its properties, replacing the previous entity and all of its existing properties if it had previously existed.

If is set to False, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist or, if the entity exists, merges the specified entity's properties with the already existing ones. Once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with updated properties provided in the request.

member.param: The collection of entities to be updated or inserted.
A flag indicating whether the operation will replace the existing entity if it already exists.
member.returns: True if all entities have been successfully updated or inserted, otherwise False.

member.name: M:Microsoft.Experience.CloudFx.Framework.Storage.ReliableCloudTableStorage.Upsert``1(System.String,System.IObservable{``0},System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enumerates through the entities returned by the specified provider and updates each entity if it already exists, or inserts a new entity if it doesn't exist in the target table. The Upsert action will save an extra roundtrip to the storage system when an application wants to insert or update an entity without needing to know if the entity already exists or not. Upsert can help increase performance and decrease latencies in the described scenario.

remarks.para: The flag tells the Windows Azure Table storage infrastructure how it should treat the existing entities.

If is set to True, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist, or if the entity exists, replace the existing one. This means that once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with its properties, replacing the previous entity and all of its existing properties if it had previously existed.

If is set to False, Upsert will insert the entity if the entity does not exist or, if the entity exists, merges the specified entity's properties with the already existing ones. Once the operation successfully completes, the table will contain the specified entity with updated properties provided in the request.

member.typeparam: The type of the table entity.
member.param: The name of the table containing the entities.
The provider supplying the entities to be either updated or inserted.
The number of entities to be batched together and sent in a single request. For optimal batch size, refer to the Windows Azure Table Storage API documentation.
A flag indicating whether the operation will replace the existing entity if it already exists.
member.returns: The object which enables the consumer to track the progress of the operation, and be notified when an error occurs or when the operation finishes.
